message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical examination findings suggest that the boy has a limp and his left pelvis sags when he stands only on his right leg. The most likely cause of these findings is damage to the right superior gluteal nerve, which supplies the gluteus medius and minimus muscles that are responsible for stabilizing the pelvis during single leg stance. The other options mentioned are less likely to be the cause of these specific findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The left pelvis sags when the boy stands on his right leg, indicating a gluteus medius muscle weakness on the left side. The most likely cause of this finding is damage to the right superior gluteal nerve, which innervates the gluteus medius muscle. The other options do not fit with the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the most likely cause is damage to the right superior gluteal nerve, which commonly causes a Trendelenburg gait. L5 radiculopathy and spinal abscess would cause more widespread symptoms, and damage to the right common peroneal nerve would likely affect both legs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The boy's limp, inability to stand on the left leg, and sagging of the left pelvis suggest a damage to the right superior gluteal nerve, which is responsible for the stability of the hip and pelvis during single-leg stance. The other options are less likely to cause these findings in a 6-year-old boy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptom of a limp suggests damage to the right superior gluteal nerve, which can cause weakness in the gluteus medius muscle and lead to Trendelenburg gait. L5 radiculopathy and spinal abscess would present with additional symptoms and abnormalities on examination. Damage to the right common peroneal nerve would also present with additional symptoms, such as foot drop or sensory deficits.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The boy’s presentation is consistent with Trendelenburg gait, which is caused by damage to the superior gluteal nerve. L5 radiculopathy would have other symptoms and signs, as well as a gradual onset. Spinal abscess would have more systemic symptoms. Damage to the right common peroneal nerve would affect the ankle and foot, not the pelvis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a limp and the physical examination shows a pelvic sag while standing on the right leg, which suggests damage to the right superior gluteal nerve. L5 radiculopathy would cause pain and numbness while spinal abscess would cause more systemic symptoms. Damage to the right common peroneal nerve may cause foot drop but not pelvic sag.

We refer to PubMed articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a limp and pelvic sag on the left side. Among the options, damage to the right superior gluteal nerve is most likely to cause this presentation. L5 radiculopathy would cause a fall to the same side as the affected nerve root. Spinal abscess would be expected to result in more widespread symptoms. Damage to the right common peroneal nerve would cause a foot drop, rather than a pelvic sag.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptom of a limp with sagging of the left pelvis when standing on the right leg suggests a damage to the right superior gluteal nerve. L5 radiculopathy would cause back pain and weakness in the leg, while spinal abscess would cause fever and back pain. Damage to the right common peroneal nerve would cause foot drop and weakness in dorsiflexion and eversion of the foot.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the left pelvis sags when he stands on his right leg suggests a damage to the right superior gluteal nerve, which controls the muscles of the hip joint and thigh. L5 radiculopathy would affect the lower back and legs, spinal abscess would have more systemic symptoms, and damage to the right common peroneal nerve would produce specific signs and symptoms in the leg.
